questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of chronic heart failure is hospitalized for a severe soft tissue infection. Cultures reveal the presence of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). Given the organism's resistance pattern and the patient's need for targeted therapy, which antibiotic is most appropriate to treat infections solely affecting the cell walls of gram-positive bacteria?

A 34-year-old woman presents with a rapidly enlarging neck mass, weight gain, and fatigue. On physical examination, there is a diffuse, non-tender goiter. Laboratory tests reveal elevated TSH and low free T4 levels. A fine needle aspiration biopsy is performed, and the histopathology image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hashimoto thyroiditis

 

Clinical Clues:

 

  • Middle-aged woman (34 years)
  • Enlarging neck mass, weight gain, fatigue – all suggest hypothyroidism
  • Diffuse, non-tender goiter
  • Elevated TSH and low free T4 – confirms primary hypothyroidism
  • Histopathology Image Features:
    • Dense lymphocytic infiltration
    • Presence of germinal centers
    • Destruction of thyroid follicles
    • Hurthle cell (oncocytic) change – large cells with abundant eosinophilic granular cytoplasm
  • These are hallmarks of Hashimoto thyroiditis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subacute thyroiditis (De Quervain's):

 

  • Usually follows a viral illness
  • Presents with painful, tender thyroid
  • Histology shows granulomatous inflammation with multinucleated giant cells, not prominent lymphoid aggregates

 

Option C. Graves' disease:

 

  • Causes hyperthyroidism (↓TSH, ↑T4)
  • Histology: hyperplastic follicles with scalloped colloid, not lymphoid infiltrates

 

Option D. Thyroid adenoma:

 

  • Solitary, well-circumscribed nodule
  • Histology: follicular pattern, no significant inflammation or Hurthle cells

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with chronic diarrhea and malabsorption. Laboratory investigations show abnormal stool composition, with increased carbohydrate content suggesting a possible carbohydrate malabsorption disorder. To confirm the presence of carbohydrates in the patient's stool sample, a biochemical test is ordered. Which of the following tests is most appropriate to detect carbohydrates in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Molisch test

 

To detect carbohydrates in a stool sample for suspected carbohydrate malabsorption, the Molisch test (Choice C) is the most appropriate.

 

Molisch test is a general qualitative test that detects the presence of any carbohydrates (monosaccharides, disaccharides, and polysaccharides). It works by dehydrating carbohydrates with concentrated sulfuric acid to form furfural derivatives, which then react with α-naphthol to produce a purple ring at the interface. This test is:

 

  • Non-specific for carbohydrate type, making it ideal for screening
  • Sensitive enough to detect carbohydrates in biological samples
  • The standard test used in clinical laboratories for detecting carbohydrates in stool

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fehling's and Option B. Benedict's tests: They are both reducing sugar tests that specifically detect monosaccharides and some disaccharides with free anomeric carbons. While they could detect some carbohydrates, they would miss non-reducing sugars and polysaccharides that might be present in malabsorption cases.

 

Option D. Seliwanoff's test: It is highly specific for ketohexoses (like fructose) and would only detect a very limited subset of carbohydrates, making it inadequate for general carbohydrate screening.

 

In carbohydrate malabsorption disorders (such as lactose intolerance, sucrase-isomaltase deficiency, or glucose-galactose malabsorption), undigested carbohydrates of various types pass into the stool. The Molisch test's broad specificity makes it the most appropriate screening test to confirm the presence of carbohydrates in this clinical context.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of HIV presents with worsening cognitive function, memory loss, and motor deficits. Imaging shows diffuse cerebral atrophy. Postmortem brain examination reveals the presence of multinucleated giant cells in the cerebral parenchyma. The formation of these giant cells is due to the fusion of which of the following cell types?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Microglial cells

 

Clinical Clues:

 

  • HIV-positive patient with:
  • Cognitive decline, memory loss, motor deficits → Consistent with HIV-associated neurocognitive disorder (HAND)
  • Diffuse cerebral atrophy on imaging
  • Postmortem finding: Multinucleated giant cells in the brain parenchyma
  • These are classic features of HIV encephalitis, a form of neuro AIDS.

 

Pathogenesis:

 

  • HIV enters the CNS early after infection via infected monocytes
  • In the brain, HIV infects microglial cells (the resident macrophages of the CNS)
  • These infected microglial cells fuse, forming multinucleated giant cells
  • The presence of these giant cells is a hallmark of HIV encephalitis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oligodendroglial cells: Myelinate CNS axons; not involved in giant cell formation

 

Option B. Neurons: Not infected by HIV and do not form multinucleated cells

 

Option C. Astrocytes: Can be infected by HIV but do not fuse to form giant cells

questions.text: A patient presents with an inflamed throat, as shown in the image. A culture from the lesion demonstrates organisms that have branching with narrowed ends. Based on this microscopic finding, what is the most likely diagnosis?
A developing embryo undergoes physiological apoptosis during organogenesis. Which of the following mechanisms is responsible for clearing apoptotic cells without causing inflammation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Efferocytosis

 

  • Apoptosis is a tightly regulated process of programmed cell death that occurs naturally during development (e.g., digit separation, organ sculpting).
  • To prevent inflammation and autoimmunity, apoptotic cells must be cleared efficiently.'
  • Efferocytosis  

 

Definition:

 

Efferocytosis is the phagocytic clearance of apoptotic cells by macrophages or neighboring cells.

 

Mechanism:

 

  • Apoptotic cells expose "eat-me" signals like phosphatidylserine on their surface.
  • Phagocytes recognize and engulf them → silent removal without triggering inflammation.

 

Importance in embryogenesis:

 

  • Ensures clean, inflammation-free removal during organ development.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exocytosis:

 

  • Process of expelling materials out of a cell.
  • Not involved in removing dead cells.

 

Option B. Pinocytosis:

 

  • Cell drinking – uptake of extracellular fluid and small molecules.
  • Not specific to apoptotic cells.

 

Option D. Entosis

 

  • Involves one live cell engulfing another live cell (seen in cancer).
  • Not a mechanism for clearing apoptotic cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Efferocytosis is the specialized, non-inflammatory mechanism used to clear apoptotic cells during embryogenesis and tissue homeostasis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of chronic alcohol use is brought to the emergency room by his family due to agitation, confusion, and aggressive behavior. His family members report that he has not eaten much in the past few days. On examination, he is disoriented, and his blood glucose level is measured at 41 mg/dL. Which of the following biochemical processes is most likely responsible for his hypoglycemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased lactate/pyruvate ratio

 

  • In chronic alcohol use, ethanol is metabolized in the liver by alcohol dehydrogenase → acetaldehyde dehydrogenase, both reactions generate NADH, so the hepatic NADH/NAD⁺ ratio rises.
  • A high NADH/NAD⁺ ratio drives pyruvate → lactate (via lactate dehydrogenase), so the lactate/pyruvate ratio increases.
  • It also drives oxaloacetate → malate, depleting oxaloacetate (OAA), a key substrate for gluconeogenesis.
  • With recent poor intake and depleted glycogen stores, the liver depends on gluconeogenesis. But because OAA is shunted away and pyruvate is pushed to lactate, gluconeogenesis is inhibited → hypoglycemia.
  • Elevated lactate also explains lactic acidosis often seen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate: Opposite: high NADH favors pyruvate → lactate; OAA is consumed to malate.

 

Option B. Increased gluconeogenesis: Would raise blood glucose, not cause hypoglycemia.

 

Option D. Decreased NADH/NAD⁺ ratio: Wrong direction; alcohol increases the NADH/NAD⁺ ratio.

 

Educational Objectives: 

 

Ethanol-induced high NADH shifts hepatic metabolism toward lactate and malate, inhibiting gluconeogenesis and causing fasting hypoglycemia.

A 42-year-old man undergoes a colectomy, and the pathologist identifies more than 100 polyps in the resected specimen along with a focus of invasive adenocarcinoma. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in a gene that regulates cell adhesion and growth. What is the functional mechanism of the gene mutation responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decreased breakdown of β-catenin

 

Clinical Scenario:

 

  • More than 100 colonic polyps + focus of adenocarcinoma strongly suggests Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP)
  • FAP is caused by a mutation in the APC gene (Adenomatous Polyposis Coli)
  • APC is a tumor suppressor gene that regulates β-catenin degradation in the Wnt signaling pathway.
  • Pathogenesis of APC Mutation:
    • Normally, APC forms a complex with other proteins (like GSK-3β and Axin) to promote β-catenin degradation
    • In FAP, mutated APC fails to degrade β-catenin
    • This leads to accumulation of β-catenin in the cytoplasm and its translocation to the nucleus
    • Nuclear β-catenin activates transcription of oncogenic genes (e.g., MYC, cyclin D1), promoting uncontrolled cell proliferation

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased breakdown of β-catenin: Opposite of what happens; APC normally promotes breakdown.

 

Option C. Lack of production of β-catenin: Would impair proliferation, not cause cancer.

 

Option D. Increased nuclear translocation of β-catenin: Is a consequence, not the primary mechanism. The mutation leads to decreased breakdown, which in turn causes increased nuclear translocation.

A 42-year-old man presents with a 2-week history of fever, weakness, and bleeding gums. Peripheral blood smear reveals pancytopenia, and a bone marrow biopsy shows 26% blasts with Auer rods and mature myeloid cells. Additionally, neutrophils with pseudo Pelger-Huet anomaly are detected. Which of the following cytochemical stains is most likely to be positive?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Myeloperoxidase

 

Clinical Clues:

 

  • Fever, weakness, bleeding gums → Suggestive of marrow failure
  • Pancytopenia + >20% blasts in bone marrow = Acute leukemia
  • Presence of Auer rods = Myeloid lineage
  • Pseudo-Pelger-Huët anomaly in neutrophils → Suggests dysplastic changes, commonly seen in myeloid disorders
  • Diagnosis: Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML)

 

Cytochemical Stains in Leukemia:

questions.text: A 1-year-old boy presents with chronic fatigue, pallor, and jaundice. Laboratory testing reveals anemia, with abnormally low levels of lactate production by his red blood cells. The low lactate level is confirmed using a radiolabeled substrate. A deficiency in which of the following enzymes is the most likely the cause of this patient’s anemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pyruvate kinase

 

RBCs rely entirely on glycolysis for ATP and convert pyruvate → lactate. Pyruvate kinase (PK) deficiency blocks the final ATP-generating step (PEP → pyruvate), so less pyruvate is made and lactate production falls, leading to ATP depletion, membrane fragility, and chronic hemolytic anemia (fatigue, pallor, jaundice in infancy).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phosphofructokinase (PFK): Its deficiency (Tarui disease) primarily causes exercise intolerance in muscle and hemolytic anemia with low lactate.

 

Option B. Glucose-6-phosphatase: Liver/kidney enzyme (von Gierke disease); absent in RBCs, doesn’t explain RBC lactate Levels.

 

Option D. G6PD: Causes oxidant-induced hemolysis via impaired NADPH/Glutathione, but glycolytic flux to lactate is not characteristically reduced.
